Alternate Name(s): lapis albanus, Peperino di Marino  [[1, 286]], Albanae [[4, 406]]
Petrographic Definition/Details: colata di fango piroclastica  [[1, 286]], quarried from a volcanic-debris flow deposit [[4, 413]]
Appearance and Composition: The term "peperino" refers to gray tufi from the Lazio with parts of crystals both white (leucite and analcime) and dark (biotite, pirocene). [[1, 290]]
Compressive Strength: < 40 Mpa [[4, 410]]; specifically, 31.3 MPa (oven-dried, standard deviation 0.8), 16.3 MPa (soaked, standard deviation 2.4), 26.6 MPa (90-98% relative humidity, standard deviation 0.9) [[5, 502]]
Quarry Location(s): {{1}} Colli Albani district [[1, 286]]! {{10}} from the Crater of Lake Albano; Deposits contained within a close area around eruptive vents [[4, 413]]; quarried at Castrimoenum, near modern-day Marino, and used locally [[8, 15]]
Dates of Use: "Accessible after the construction of the Via Appia, 312 BCE [[4, 427]]; used in the late Republic and early Imperial Period [[5, 504]]

Alternate Name(s): lapis gabinus,  [[1, 286]], Gabine tufa, sperone [[4, 406]], but the latter term should be avoided due to ambiguity [[4, 403]]
Petrographic Definition/Details: deposito piroclastico idromagmatico  [[1, 286]], quarried from a pyroclastic surge deposit [[4, 413]]
Appearance and Composition: Dark and greyish. stratified into levels , whose superficial layers erode at different speeds and in different ways. [[1, 290]] The only stratified Roman tufo [[1,292]]
Compressive Strength: Uniaxial: 39.5 MPa (oven-dried, standard deviation 10.5), 15.5 MPa (soaked, standard deviation 3.4), 23 MPa (90-98% relative humidity, standard deviation 6.3) [[5, 502]]
Quarry Location(s): {{1}} Colli Albani district [[1, 286]]! {{8}} the crater of Castiglione [[1, 289-90]]! {{9}} near the old city of Gabi [[1,290]]! Deposits contained within a close area around eruptive vents [[4, 413]]; local use, mostly at Rome [[8, 24]]
Dates of Use: Late Republic and early Imperial Period [[5, 504]]

Alternate Name(s): Granular grey tufa, Peperino della Via Flaminia, Peperino Grigio [[1, 286]]; Tufo pisolitico, tufo granulare grigio, cappellaccio [[4, 406]], but the latter should be avoided for ambiguity
Petrographic Definition/Details: Colata piroclastica idromagmatica  [[1, 286]], quarried from ignimbrite, an unstructured deposit produced by pyroclastic flow [[4, 413]]
Appearance and Composition: Yellowish-grey with some green tones. Compact structure, fine granulometry of components, superficially inconsistent, . Composed of a heterogeneous association of volcanic fragments and sediment, immersed in a partly zeolite and often argillated glassy matrix   [[1, 287]]
General Density: Low- about 122 kg/m<sup>3</sup> [[1, 287]]; Peperino della Via Flaminia variety: 1890 kg/m<sup>3</sup> [[5, 502]];
Flexural Strength: Peperino della Via Flaminia variety: 9.09 MPa (dry), 4.88 MPa (wet) [[5, 501]]
Compressive Strength: Via Flaminia variety, uniaxial strengths: 43.4 MPa (oven-dried, 14.3 standard deviation), 28.8 MPa (soaked, 12.1 standard deviation), 27.2 MPa (90-98% humidity, 6.0 standard deviation) [[5, 502]]
Water Absorption: 33% (soaked) [[5, 501]]; Peperino della Via Flaminia variety: 20% (soaked), 4.47% (98% relative humidity) [[5, 501]]
Quarry Location(s): {{1}} Colli Albani district  [[1, 286]]! {{2}} Base of the Campidoglio! {{3}} Base of the Palatino! [[1, 287]]. Found at the bases of hills. [[1, 281]], Aventine; used at Rome  [[8, 48]]
Dates of Use: Mostly used during the seventh through fifth centuries BCE [[4, 420]]; Use continued until 390 CE when it was substituted by rock with stronger mechanical charactaristics and better aesthetics [[1, 287]].

Alternate Name(s): Sperone  [[1, 286]], but this ambiguous term should be avoided [[4, 403]]
Appearance and Composition: Brown-gray. Rich in fragments of lava and crystal [[1, 289]]
Compressive Strength: Uniaxial strengths: 36.7 MPa (oven-dried, standard deviation 4.9), 17.3 MPa (soaked, standard deviation 2.8), 25.1 MPa (90-98% humidity, standard deviation 3.2) [[5, 502]]
Quarry Location(s): {{1}} Colli Albani district [[1, 286]]! {{7}} Monte Tusculo in the Colli Albani, active until the first century BC. [[1, 289]] Deposits contained within a close area around eruptive vents [[4, 413]]; Used locally, mostly at Rome [[8, 58]]
Dates of Use: Late Republic and early Imperial Period [[5, 504]]

Alternate Name(s): lapis ruber, lapis pallens, Tufo giallo di Grotta Oscura  [[1, 286]], tufo giallo porosa [[4, 406]]
Petrographic Definition/Details: Colata piroclastica  [[1, 286]], quarried from ignimbrite, an unstructured deposit produced by pyroclastic flow [[4, 413]]
Age: 548,000 years old +/- 4,000 (upper eruptive subunits), 561,000 +/- 4,000 years old (lower eruptive subunits) [[4, 406]]
Appearance and Composition: Yellow, with some dark grey. Made of yellow pumice, including carbon and more. [[1, 291]] Glassy and porous, "poorly to moderately cemented" [[4, 413]]
General Density: Between 1224 and 1275 kg/m<sup>3</sup> [[1, 291]] - or as high as 1520 kg/m<sup>3</sup> [[4, 424]]
Compressive Strength: between 6 and 9 MPa [[1,291]]; or, uniaxial strengths: 22.9 MPa (oven-dried, standard deviation 4.1), 7.6 MPa (soaked, standard deviation 0.7), 9.8 MPa (90-98% humidity, standard deviation 0.8) [[5, 502]]
Quarry Location(s): {{11}} Sabatine district [[1, 286]]! {{12}} taken up to 13 km from the Via Tiberina, no longer available because the land has been covered in more recent formations. [[1, 291]], "Near Grotta Oscura and northward along Via Tiberina" [[4, 410]] Pyroclastic flows traveled far from their eruptive vents, meaning the rock was widespread and varied from one site to the other. [[4, 418]]; Local use, mostly at Rome [[8, 26]]
Dates of Use: Quarried after Roman conquest of Fidenae and Veio in 426 and 396 BCE [[4, 427]]

Compressive Strength: Uniaxial strengths: 20.4 MPa (oven-dried, standard deviation 1.7), 9.8 MPa (soaked, standard deviation 1.1), 14.1 MPa (90-98% relative humidity, 2.3 standard deviation) [[5, 502]]
Quarry Location(s): {{11}} Sabatine District; South of the deposits of Tufo Giallo della Via Tiberina, along Via Tiberina and Via Flaminia, as well as at Prima Porta [[4, 419]]

Alternate Name(s): lapis ruber, Tufo litoide Lionato, Tufo dell'Aniene, Tufo di Monteverde  [[1, 286]], Anio, lapidicinis Rubris [[4, 406]]
Petrographic Definition/Details: Colata piroclastica  [[1, 286]], quarried from ignimbrite, an unstructured deposit produced by pyroclastic flow [[4, 413]]
Appearance and Composition: Aniene River varieties: light brown, well consolidated, 12-20% lava with yellowish-brown pumice fragments; varieties south of Rome:  light brown to grayish orange, less consolidated, <10% lava, light  brown to dark yellowish-orange pumice fragments; Monteverde area varieties: mostly white phillipsite cement, minimal clay, varies in color [[4, 433]]
General Density: Between 1200 and 1710 kg/m<sup>3</sup> [[1,288]]; Salone quarry:  1720 kg/m<sup>3</sup> [[5, 502]]
Flexural Strength: Lunghezza: 3.72-4.16 MPa (dry), 2.61-3.14 MPa (wet); Salone: 2.62-3.74 MPa (dry), 2.84-2.98 MPa (wet); Tor Cervara: 2.56 MPa (dry), 2.02 MPa (wet); Rupe Tarpea: 1.77 MPa (dry), 1.15 MPa (wet); Via Sapori: 4.34 MPa (dry) [[5, 501]]
Compressive Strength: General: < 40 Mpa [[4, 410]]; Salone Quarry, uniaxial: 28.5 MPa (oven-dried, standard deviation 2.4), 15.9 MPa (soaked, standard deviation 2.5), 25.8 MPa (98% relative humidity, standard deviation 6.6) [[5, 502]]
Water Absorption: Lunghezza: 25-26% (soaked), 3.76% (98% relative humidity); Salone: 18-19% soaked, 4.09% (98% relative humidity); Tor Cervara and Rupe Tarpea: 31% soaked; Via Sapori: 26% soaked; Via Portuense: 27% soaked [[5, 501]]
Quarry Location(s): {{1}} Colli Albani district  [[1, 286]] Found at the tops of hills [[1, 281]]! {{4}} On the right bank of the Tiber- what is now Monteverde [[1, 282]]! {{5}} Along the Aniene (Teverone) River, which flows from the Tiber [[1, 282]]! - quarried at Tor Cervara, Settecamini, Salone, and Lunghezza in the 2nd century BCE [[4, 420]] {{6}} occasionally, in small quantities Tufo Rosso with black spots is found in caves in the area now called Fidene, about 10 KM north of Rome along the Tiber [[1, 282]] Base of the Capitoline Hill [[4, 420]] Pyroclastic flows traveled far from their eruptive vents, meaning the rock was widespread and varied from one site to the other. [[4, 418]]. Local use, mostly at Rome [[8, 50]]
Dates of Use: Early Romans used the weaker, glassy varieties quarried from the Capitoline and Monteverde, while the stronger varieties quarried along the Aniene became prominent during the late 2nd century BCE [[4, 428]]

Alternate Name(s): lapis fidenae, Tufo di Fidene, Tufo Rosso Litoide  [[1, 286]], Fidenates [[4, 406]]
Appearance and Composition: dark red with black slag; or, light brown with dark gray fragments [[4, 418]]
Quarry Location(s): {{11}} Sabatine district  [[1, 286]]! {{13}} found primarily in the quarries of Fidene about 10 km north of Rome on the Tiber [[1, 292]]! Covers a vast area. {{14}} Veio [[1, 292]]! {{15}} Isola Farnese [[1, 292]]! {{16}} Castel Giubileo [[1, 292]]! {{17}} Prima Porta [[1, 292]]! {{18}} Saxa Rubra [[1, 292]]; local use, mostly at Rome [[8, 23]]
Dates of Use: First used by the Etruscans, used by the Romans primarily between 390 and 210 BCE, and less frequently until the Imperial period. [[1, 292]]. Quarried after Roman conquest of Fidenae and Veio in 426 and 396 BCE, but not common in Late Republican buildings [[4, 427]].

Quarry Location(s): Quarried at Ain-Smara, near Constantine, modern Algeria; local and regional use [[8, 4]]
Eastern Desert of Egypt, Mons Berenicides, NW of Berenike; regional use [[8, 39]]

Appearance and Composition: Dark red and pink, streaked with "yellow ochre or cream-white" [[8, 20]]
Quarry Location(s): Djebel Oust, 25 km south of Tunis, Tunisia; local and regional use [[8, 20]]
Local use, with quarries at Hereke, coast of Turkey, near Gebze [[8, 28]]
Quarried at Molli, Tegoia, and Montarrenti, near Sienna, Italy; local use, possibly exported [[8, 40]]

Appearance and Composition: Similar to pavonazzetto [[8, 26]], a name that refers to purple/gray veins [[3, 27]]
Quarry Location(s): Quarried at Göynükören, Upper Tembris valley, Turkey; local use [[8, 26]]
Quarried at Akrini, near Kozani, modern Greece; local and inter-regional use [[8, 4]]
Exported regionally from Roselle, Grosseto province of Italy [[8, 48]]

Appearance and Composition: Yellow, "with grey streaks and rose patches" [[8, 34]]
Quarry Location(s): "Quarried at La-Pène-Saint- Martin

Stone Name: Lady, right bank of the Garonne, France, across from Saint- Béat; exported regionally [[8, 34]]"
Alternate Name(s): Imperial period, esp. from the Trajanic period onward (early 2nd century CE) [[8, 34]]

Quarry Location(s): Quarried at Barxeta, 50 km S of Valencia, Spain; exported regionally in Roman times [[8, y]]

Appearance and Composition: Dark golden yellow…with spirals of yellow and cream-white, some grey [[8, 28]]
Quarry Location(s): Quarried at Henchir el Kasbat, ancient Thuburbo Maius, Tunisia, and exported regionally [[8, 28]]

Appearance and Composition: gray-black "with circular veins and streaks in grey-white" [[8, 32]]
Quarry Location(s): Quarried at Kourelos, Mani peninsula, Greece; esp. exported to Rome [[8, 32]]
Dates of Use: Exported between regions by the 2nd century CE [[8, 32]]

Alternate Name(s): peperino grigio/rosso, peperino di Viterbo, peperino duro; peperino Soriano, peperino Vitorchiano [[9]]
Appearance and Composition: gray/red/pink [[9]], similar to lapis albanus/peperino [[Vitruvius, De Architectura 2.7.3]]
Quarry Location(s): Region of the Tarquinii, modern Viterbo, Lazio, Italy; quarried around Lake Bolsena and in the Statonia prefecture [[Vitr. 2.7.3]]
Quarried at Bussoleno, near Susa, Italy, local use [[8, 12]]

Alternate Name(s): granitello antico [[1, 317]], granito grigio minuto del Giglio [[8, 29]]
Quarry Location(s): {{31}}: Italy, Tuscany, Island of Giglio. [[1, 317]], east coast; local and regional (mostly Rome) use [[8, 29]]
Quarried at Nicotera, NW Calabria, Italy; used locally and across Italy [[8, 43]]
Quarried at Alconera, near Badajoz, modern Spain; local and regional use [[8, 4]]

Alternate Name(s): cappellaccio, although this ambiguous term should be avoided [[4, 406]]
Petrographic Definition/Details: Quarried from ignimbrite, an unstructured deposit produced by pyroclastic flow [[4, 413]]
Appearance and Composition: Olive gray with several white leucite fragments, some of which have been replaced by analcime [[4, 419]]
Quarry Location(s): Monti Sabatini volcano, with outcrops atop the Palatine Hill [[4, 419]]
Quarried at Saint-Béat, central Pyrenees, France, and later "exported across most of southern and western Gaul" [[8, 49]]
Dates of Use: Local use from late 1st century BCE, exported in the Imperial Period [[8, 49]]

Appearance and Composition: white, "with distinct blue and grey streaks" [[8, 13]]
Quarry Location(s): Quarried from the cliff Cap de Garde, 12 km from Annaba, Algeria; local and regional use [[8, 13]]
Quarried at Doliana, in the Tegea territory of Arcadia, Greece; local use [[8, 20]]
Used locally, with quarries at Ntikali, southern Crete [[8, 43]]

Alternate Name(s): marmor hymettium, Hymettus marble, marmo dell'Imetto, marmo cipolla, imezio. [[1, 316]]
Appearance and Composition: Grey/blue/beige [[1, 316]]; or, white with gray veins [[8, 41]]
Quarry Location(s): {{26}}: Greece, Athens, Mount Hymettus. [[1, 316]]
Dates of Use: Local use from the Classical period (dates?), inter-regional exportation during Roman times [[8, 41]]

Quarry Location(s): Quarried at Megara, central Megarid, Greece; local use from Archaic period onwards [[8, 39]]

Petrographic Definition/Details: subarkosic arenite to quartz arenite sandstone [[2]]
Quarry Location(s): Nile Valley: Roman quarries at Nag el-Dumariyya village, East Bank; Gebel el-Silsila, East and West Bank; Nag el-Hosh village, West Bank; Gharb el-Gaafra district, East Bank; Gharb Aswan district, West Bank; E and SE of Aswan city, East Bank; under Lake Nasser, West Bank; north of Qasr Ibrim ruins, East Bank; Eastern Desert: Wadi el Muweih, Wadi el-Kanayis; Western Desert: Bahariya Oasis, Dakhla Oasis, Kharga Oasis [[2]]
Dates of Use: Greek inscriptions at El Hosh indicate occupation until at least the reign of Antoninus Pius (mid-2nd century CE) [[8, 21]]

Quarry Location(s): Quarried at Els Munts, 16 km E of Tarragona, Spain [[8, 22]]; and Platja dels Capellans, 15 km E of Tarragona; local use [[8, 45]]
Quarried at El Llorito, just east of Tarragona, Spain; mostly used at Tarragona during Roman times [[8, 21]]
Coves del Llorito, near Tarragona, Spain; local use [[8, 17]]
Local use, with quarries at and around Tarragona, Spain: El Médol [[8, 22]], Mas del Marquès [[8, 38]], Platja l'Arrabassada [[8, 45]], and Punta de la Creueta [[8, 46]]
Used locally with quarries at Clots de Sant Julià [[8, 17]] and Puig d’en Torró, near Girona, Spain [[8, 46]]; and Domeny, in Girona [[8, 20]]
Local use during Roman times, with quarries at Sant Marti d’Empúries, near Empúries, Spain [[8, 50]]

Appearance and Composition: pink-brown groundmass with pink phenocrysts (crystals) and colorless/bluish quartz [[2]]
Quarry Location(s): {{8}}: Eastern Egyptian desert: Gebel Dokhan (Mons Porphyrites) [[8, 40]] and Wadi Abu Gerida, 10 km NW of Maghrabiya [[8, 60]]
Dates of Use: Imperial Period [[8, 40]], specifically 1st to 2nd century CE at Wadi Abu Gerida [[2]]

Quarry Location(s): Quarried at Alconera, near Badajoz, modern Spain; local and regional use [[8, 4]]

{{29}}: Greece, Laconia, Peninsula of Mani. [[1, 316]], quarried at Laghia-Dimaristika, Marmaro, Mianes/Kokkinoghia, Platsa, Profitis Elias, Vathia, and exported between regions [[8, 35, 38, 45, 46, 59]]
Used locally and quarried from the Sarno Valley, E of Pompeii, Italy [[8, 51]]

Appearance and Composition: Similar to pavonazzetto [[8, 4]], a name that refers to purple/gray veins [[3, 27]]
Quarry Location(s): Quarried at Alconera, near Badajoz, modern Spain; local and regional use [[8, 4]]
Local use, with quarries near Tarragona, Spain, at Coves de la Pedrera [[8, 17]]; Mas dels Arcs [[8, 38]]; Pedreres de l’Aqüeducte [[8, 44]]; and Torre d’en Dolça [[8, 57]]
Quarried at Caerwent, SE Wales, Britain; local use [[8, 13]]
Quarried at Farnham, in the Weald, SE England; used at Silchester (probably) [[8, 23]]

Alternate Name(s): Gris Anasol, Anasol Macael, Anasol Marble
Quarry Location(s): Quarried at Macael, in the Almeria province of Spain [[8, 37]]

Flexural Strength: 12.1-14.2 MPa [[9]], or as high as 22.85 MPa?
Compressive Strength: 81.1-87.4 MPa [[9]], or as high as 134.0 MPa?
Water Absorption: 0.1-0.2% at atmospheric pressure; or as low as 0.05% [[9]]
Quarry Location(s): Quarried at Macael in the Almeria province of Spain; exported across southern Spain [[8, 37]]
Quarried at Borba, near Estremoz, modern Portugal; local and probably regional use [[8, 11]]

Alternate Name(s): Marmi Rosso di Verona, Red Verona Marble [[9]]
Appearance and Composition: Red-pink [[8, 59]]; "light orange red to dark red with nodules and partly stylolitic veins" [[9]]
Quarry Location(s): Exported regionally in small amounts from Verona, just east of Lake Garda, Italy [[8, 59]]

Appearance and Composition: Medium-grained, pink/light green/cream-white [[8, 14]]; the variety at Isole Marmorata was less pink, more gray [[8, 29]]
Quarry Location(s): Quarried at Capo Testa, northern Sardinia [[8, 14]]; Olbia, NE Sardinia [[8, 43]]; Isole Marmorata, off the coast of northern Sardinia [[8, 29]]; Porto Rotondo, NE Sardinia; local and regional use, mostly exported to Rome or elsewhere in Italy  [[8, 46]]

Alternate Name(s): possibly the same as Breccia Carsica/Napoleon Slivia/Breccia Aurisina Marble [[9]]
Quarry Location(s): Aurisina, just north of Trieste, in Italy; local use, esp. at Trieste and Aquileia [[8, 7]]

Alternate Name(s): Parian marble, lychnites  [[1, 315]]; paria lithos [[8, 16]]; Marathi Marble [[9]]
Quarry Location(s): {{20}}: Greece, Aegean, Island of Paros  [[1, 315]]. Three varieties: Paros-1 quarried at Marathi [[8, 37]], Paros-2 at Choridaki Valley, both widely exported in Roman times [[8, 16]]; Paros-3 at Agios Minas, Central Paros - local, regional, inter-regional use [[8, 3]]
